gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Philadelphia Police Department--Crime Analysis and Mapping

gmd:metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Philadelphia Police Department Crime Analysis and Mapping Unit

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: The shapefile is the administrative boundaries for Police Sectors. Sectors are the logical means by which police districts are subdivided. Each district is made up of 12-30 sectors. In theory, a police patrol car is assigned to each sector and a supervisor for each 3-4 sectors. Feature Update Date: 03-2010

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: The sector coverage was developed for cartographic production, reporting, re-deployment and analysis purposes within the PPD.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Philadelphia Police Department - Crime Analysis and Mapping unit

gmd:environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.4000

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: publication date

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Philadelphia Police Department - Crime Analysis and Mapping unit

gmd:orderingInstructions.gco:CharacterString: Please contact the Deputy Commissioner of Science and Technology at 215-686-1227 or the Crime Analysis and Mapping Unit at 215-686-1577.

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: The attributes were checked by individual districts for accuracy.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Had to re-align the sector boundaries to account for the 92nd district going away.

Updated sector boundaries within the new 22nd District. The new 22nd District now encompasses what used to be both the 22nd & 23rd Districts. The sectors were changed to reflect this new district boundary change.

The Crime Analysis and Mapping group requested and received paper-based descriptions of the district and sector outlines. These included paper maps and text descriptions of the bounding streets of each sector. Based on the District coverage digitized and snapped to the street centerline by Jim Querry in summer 1997, the districts were subdivided into Sectors using ArcView 3.0a. Due to the limitations of ArcView, these sector boudaries were not snapped to the Street Centerline. In the process, several discrepancies were discovered in the earlier work by MOIS, mostly in the areas bordering the parks and a missing district at the airport.

Due to changes in the street centerline caused by rectification to the planimetrics derived from 1996 orthophotography, it was necessary to re-digitize the sectors. This was also driven by a need to send street, boundary and other files to PRC/Litton for use in a real-time mapping system being developed for the radio dispatch center at Police Headquarters. Brian Ivey at MOIS accomplished this second version of the sectors in Arc/Info 7.2.1 by 1)converting the shapefiles to coverages; 2)cleaning and building the coverages; 3) using SNAPCOVER to snap the coverage to a layer that combined the street centerline, railways, parks and rivers; 4) re-joining the attributes to the coverage (lost in SHAPEARC) and 5) outputting as an export file for transfer. This process was done to satisfy PRC, but at this date, the street centerline rectification project had not yet been completed.

Using the coverage developed by Brian Ivey at MOIS as a starting point Kevin Switala at the Police Department used ArcInfo 8 Beta 1 to re-do the the process. A minor error had been reported by the 8th District on Sector S and the rectification of the street centerline had been completed and delivered. Kevin used the same process as above using Workstation Arc/Info.
Police Department is in the process of re-sectoring all districts - changes will be frequent through 2001.

District boundary changes between the 6th/9th and the 3rd/17th took place December 15th, which necessitated a change in the sector and division layer. To maintain vertex integrity between the division, district and sector, a non-dircect method was used using ArcView3.1. The district layer was changed prior to the sector change and was utilized to maintain integrity during this process. 1. Clip 6th's and 9th's SECTORS with the new 6th and 9th DISTRICTS. 2. With the original SECTOR layer (subsetted to the 6th and 9th), performed an intersection with the new 6th and 9th DISTRICTS. This resulted in a strip of polys one block wide between South an Lombard streets. 3. These polys were pasted into the SECTOR layer that resulted from step #1. Verticies were snapped, if needed. 4. Any subsetted SECTOR layers were merged back together to create a new SECTOR layer for the entire city.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Philadelphia Police Department - Crime Analysis and Mapping Unit

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Subsequent examination by Brian Ivey revealed that the 'snapped' coverages were not properly snapped and will require additional work. A visual display indicates that they line up, but in fact, they do not if zoomed sufficiently.

There was a three way trade-off of sectors between the 14th, 35th, and 39th district. The process was completed using the subtract and union commands contained in the Geo-processing Wizard extension of ArcView3.2 The district/sector changes are outlined in the table below: 35L to 14A 35N to 14B 35O to 14C 35P to 14Q 14A to 39S 14B to 39T 14C to 39U 14Q to 39V 14Y to 39W Other attributes of the sector polygons, such as car number, were also changed

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Philadelphia Police Department - Crime Analysis and Mapping Unit

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Police Headquarters, Rm 211 One Franklin Square

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: District boundary changes between the 16th and 19th took place December 15th, which necessitated a change in the sector layer attributes (sect_code, dist_num,rpc_num, and distsec_id). 19s became 16s 19v became 16q 19t became 16r 19u became 16p

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Philadelphia Police Department - Crime Analysis and Mapping Unit

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: The Philadelphia Police Dept. Became responsible for policing of the Philadelphia Naval Yard as of April 1st, 2000. Consequently, that part of the 1st District was split in two sectors divided by Broad Street.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Philadelphia Police Department - Crime Analysis and Mapping Unit

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Brian Ivey (MOIS) returned an ArcInfo export file of our sectors with the boundaries snapped to the street centerlines. He used a series of commands in ArcEdit to re-construct the boundaries using the composite layer (which includes rail, hydro, street centerlines, and the citywide boundary).

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Mayor's Office of Information Services - GIS Services Group

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: The boundary between the 6th and 9th district changed slightly such that City Hall falls in the 6th as opposed to the 9th. There were no other changes along Broad Street except around City Hall. 1. Only changed verticies for Q and J sectors in the 6th district. Accuracy was good enought to ensure that the sector boundry was never more than 3 feet from the street centerline. This ensures that spatial selections of INCT data will associate with the correct sector and district. 2. Snapped sector G (9th district) verticies to the ones edited above.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Philadelphia Police Department - Crime Analysis and Mapping Unit

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: There has been a little known error in the PPD's district and sector shapefile. The Benjamin Franklin Parkway (from SW to NE curblines and down to Love Park) is actually within the Park Division and not the 9th district. While this makes for an awkward boundary, it was decided to alter it using the street curblines layer as opposed to the centerline. The polygons were edited in ArcInfo 8.1 using the following commands: shapearc, clean, regionpoly, createlabel, idedit, put, extend, clean, and arcshape. Split and merge commands were also used. Hence, both sector T and U have non-contiguous polygons on either side of the parkway.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Philadelphia Police Department - Crime Analysis and Mapping Unit

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Police Headquarters, Rm 211 One Franklin Square

gmd:alternateTitle.gco:CharacterString: STREETS: Curb Edges, Other Transportation Features

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Composite coverage supplied by Streets department. Arcs were selected from the composite coverage and put into a new coverage. Arcs not present in the composite coverage that were needed for boundaries were derived from the curbline coverage or from the orthophotography.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Philadelphia Police Department - Crime Analysis and Mapping Unit

gmd:deliveryPoint.gco:CharacterString: Police Headquarters, Rm 211 One Franklin Square

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Benjamin Franklin Pkwy, once in the Park District (92nd) was given to the 9th District. Sector boundaries were updated to reflect this change

After completing work on a project to compile a map coverage of subsector boundaries, there were errors discovered in the sector boundaries of the 19th District. Based on information provided by the 19th District Captain, these sector boundaries were corrected.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: STREETS: Curb Edges, Other Transportation Features
